case_vignette:
A 31-year-old woman visits the clinic with chronic diarrhea on most days for the past four months. She also complains of lower abdominal discomfort and cramping, which is relieved by episodes of diarrhea. She denies any recent change in her weight. Bowel movements are preceded by a sensation of urgency, associated with mucus discharge, and followed by a feeling of incomplete evacuation. The patient went camping several months earlier, and another member of her camping party fell ill recently. Her temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A routine stool examination is within normal limits and blood test results show:
Hb%   13 gm/dL
Total count (WBC):   11,000/mm3
Differential count:    
  Neutrophils: 70%
  Lymphocytes: 25%
  Monocytes: 5%
ESR:   10 mm/hr
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been having chronic diarrhea most days for the past four months, and I feel discomfort and cramping in my lower belly, which gets better after I go to the bathroom.
Have you had any changes in your weight or appetite?
No, I haven't noticed any recent change in my weight.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new foods or environments?
Yes, I went camping several months ago.
Have you had any recent stressful events or changes in your daily routine?
The case vignette does not provide information about recent stressful events or changes in my daily routine.
Have you had any recent surgeries or medical procedures?
No, I haven't had any recent surgeries or medical procedures.
Have you had any recent allergic reactions or skin rashes?
No, I haven't had any allergic reactions or skin rashes.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or appetite?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my sleep patterns or appetite.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication regimen?
The case vignette does not provide information about changes in my medication regimen.
Have you had any recent changes in your family history of gastrointestinal disorders?
The case vignette does not provide information about changes in my family history of gastrointestinal disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
